title: 111_hr5348
content: The "Federal Workforce Reduction Act of 2010" aims to reduce the number of federal employees. The "Federal Workforce Reduction Act of 2010" includes provisions for a hiring freeze in Executive agencies during fiscal years with projected budget deficits. The President will establish a Federal workforce hiring pool for appointments in all agencies. The "Federal Workforce Reduction Act of 2010" allows Executive agencies to appoint individuals to positions if approved by the President through a request process with specific criteria and regulations. The "Federal Workforce Reduction Act of 2010" outlines the criteria for the President to approve requests from Executive agencies for appointing individuals to positions. The number of positions in the Federal workforce hiring pool starts at zero in fiscal year 2011 and increases by 0.50 for each vacant position while decreasing by 1.0 for each request for a full-time equivalent position. The President can waive the hiring restrictions in cases of emergency or national security concerns. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management will implement this subsection, consulting with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. Reports to Congress must be submitted within 90 days. The President must report to Congress within 90 days of each quarter on approved appointments, detailing positions without revealing individual identities. Reports must be made public on the Executive Office of the President's website. The President must report approved appointments to Congress quarterly, without revealing individual identities, and make the reports public on the Executive Office of the President's website. Certain executive agencies are excluded from this requirement.
